commander.name: Oberst Hans-Georg Hildebrandt
commander.previous_service: Assumed command after Generalmajor von Randow KIA 21 Dec 1942. Promoted Generalmajor 1 March 1943.

artillery.note: Reduced artillery due to losses. Kampfgruppe organization limits heavy artillery support.

soft_skin_vehicles.note: Severely reduced from losses during El Alamein retreat. Kampfgruppe organization.

supply_logistics.supply_status: POOR - Division severely understrength after El Alamein disaster. Reinforced with tanks (91 total) but chronic fuel/ammunition shortages. Extended supply lines from Sicily/Italy to Tunisia. Allied air superiority disrupts logistics. Operating as battle groups (Kampfgruppen) due to fragmentation.
notes: Reduced to 4 tanks by late Nov 1942, reinforced to 91 by Feb 1943
Chronic fuel shortages limit operations
Allied air attacks on supply convoys from Sicily
Kampfgruppe organization reflects supply/organizational collapse

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisian mountains - Kasserine Pass, Faïd Pass, Maizila Pass. Atlas Mountains foothills. Rocky, mountainous terrain with narrow passes.
notes: Mountain passes key to operations
Cold winter weather in mountains
Rain/mud limit tank mobility
Narrow passes create bottlenecks

subordinate_units.note: Battle group for Kasserine Pass operations - northern attack toward Le Kef
Battle group for Kasserine Pass operations - western encirclement at Sidi Bou Zid
Artillery, engineers, reconnaissance, signals, logistics (severely reduced)

tactical_doctrine.role: Panzer division reorganized as battle groups (Kampfgruppen) for Kasserine Pass offensive. Mission: Destroy US II Corps, recapture initiative in Tunisia. Coordinated attack with 10th Panzer Division.
special_capabilities: Kampfgruppe flexibility - combined arms battle groups
Skilled at mobile defense and counterattack
known_issues: Severely understrength - division fragmented into battle groups
Allied air superiority prevents daylight movement
Commander Hildebrandt criticized by Rommel for 'dawdling' at Sbiba
Tank losses unsustainable - no replacements available

historical_context.operational_status: Active but severely depleted - Battle of Kasserine Pass (February 1943)
major_battles: Battle of Sidi Bou Zid (14-15 February 1943): Destroyed 100 US tanks, 1,600 casualties inflicted
Battle of Kasserine Pass (19-22 February 1943): Attack toward Le Kef/Sbiba stalled by US minefields
notes: Division reduced to 4 tanks by late November 1942 after El Alamein
Reinforced to 91 tanks by February 1943 for Kasserine offensive
Commander von Randow KIA 21 Dec 1942 (British mine near Tripoli)
Hildebrandt assumed command 1 Jan 1943, promoted Generalmajor 1 March 1943
Division fragmented into Kampfgruppen Schuette and Stenkhoff
Rommel criticized Hildebrandt for slow attack at Sbiba ('dawdling')
140 total German tanks (both 10th and 21st Panzer) at Kasserine
Final surrender 13 May 1943

source: WebSearch: 21st Panzer Division Kasserine Pass February 1943
known_gaps: Exact tank type breakdown (91 total known, types estimated)
Personnel numbers estimated from depleted division status
notes: Q1 1943: Division in TUNISIA (Kasserine Pass area)
Division severely understrength - organized as battle groups
Reinforced from 4 tanks (Nov 1942) to 91 tanks (Feb 1943)
Commander: Oberst Hildebrandt (from 1 Jan 1943)
Major battles: Sidi Bou Zid (14-15 Feb), Kasserine Pass (19-22 Feb)
Tier 2 classification due to estimated equipment and Kampfgruppe details
Used 1942-Q4 baseline with 1943-Q1 Tunisia delta changes

primary_sources: WebSearch - Battle of Kasserine Pass sources
known_gaps: Exact tank variant breakdown unknown (91 total confirmed)
Personnel reduced from losses - exact numbers estimated
Supply details estimated from historical situation
